Santa Cruz. All participants in the journalism boot camp were professional science journalists.</small>
=== Workshops and Conferences on Computational Astrophysics ===
To further its mission in astronomy and education across the UC system, and to enable researchers in the field of AstroComputing to share and further their research through cross fertilization and collaboration, UC-HiPACC sponsors conferences on topics in computational astrophysics.
==== Future of AstroComputing Workshop (2010) ====
In December 2010 UC-HiPACC organized a major conference on the Future of AstroComputing<ref name=2010AnnualReport>{{cite web|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/2010AnnualReport.html|title=UC-HiPACC 2010 Annual Report|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=UC Santa Cruz|accessdate=7 Jan 2014}}</ref> at the [[San Diego Supercomputer Center]] at the [[University of California, San Diego]] (SDSC). UC-HiPACC provided partial support for the Enzo<ref>{{cite web|title=Enzo|url=http://lca.ucsd.edu/projects/enzo|work=Enzo version 2.0|publisher=UC San Diego|accessdate=10 Jan 2014}}</ref> workshop<ref name=PhysOrg>{{cite web|url=http://lca.ucsd.edu/workshops/enzo2010/|title=Enzo Workshop at UCSD|publisher=UC San Diego|accessdate=7 Jan 2014}}</ref> at UCSD in spring 2010.
==== 2012 Science Journalism Boot Camp in Computational Astronomy ====
In June 2012, science and engineering journalists — whose publications and productions are estimated to collectively reach more than 10 million readers and viewers worldwide — attended the first journalism “boot camp” on computational astronomy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/2012CAJBC.html|title=Computational Astronomy: From Planets to Cosmos webpage|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=UC Santa Cruz|accessdate=7 Jan 2014}}</ref> Called “Computational Astronomy: From Planets to Cosmos,” the workshop was an intense three-and-a-half-day backgrounder for practicing science or engineering journalists from all media — print, online, broadcast, social media, and film — whether on staff or freelance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/Homepage_Posts.php#3|title=First Science Journalism Boot Camp in Computational Astronomy Held at UCSC|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=UC Santa Cruz|accessdate=7 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bell|first=Trudy E.|title=From ScienceWriters: A computational astronomy boot camp|url=http://www.nasw.org/sciencewriters-computational-astronomy-boot-camp|work=ScienceWriters magazine|publisher=The National Association of Science Writers|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2012 Science Engineering Journalism Boot Camp PlayList|url=http://shelf3d.com/Search/2012%2BScience+Engineering%2BJournalism%2BBoot%2BCamp%2BPlayListIDPLE86A2876BF2D62BF|publisher=shelf3d|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref>
==== Santa Cruz Galaxy Workshops ====
Five-day workshops for galaxy researchers worldwide co-sponsored by UC-HiPACC were held at UCSC in August in 2010, 2011, 2012, and 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=HiPACC Conferences & Workshops|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/Conferences.html|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=University of California, Santa Cruz|accessdate=7 Jan 2014}}</ref> The most recent, in August 2013, was attended by nearly 90 participants from about 30 institutions in Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Israel, Korea, Spain, and the United States. Approximately 50 sessions were held over five days. About 85 presenters from around the world conducted sessions on a variety of current concerns in astrophysics.<ref>{{cite web|title=2013 Santa Cruz Galaxy Workshop|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/GalaxyWorkshop2013.html|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=University of California, Santa Cruz|accessdate=7 Jan 2014}}</ref>
=== Annual Summer School in Computational Astrophysics ===
UC-HiPACC supports an annual international advanced school aimed at graduate students and postdocs who are currently working in or actively interested in doing research in AstroComputing. Topics and locations of the annual school rotate among the UC campuses and national laboratories, and [[Caltech]] and [[Stanford]] also participate. Lectures from summer school sessions are posted on the UC-HiPACC website so that they can be useful worldwide. During these schools, students are afforded direct access to some of the largest supercomputers in the world for running their own simulations.<ref>{{cite web|title=The International Summer School on AstroComputing|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/SummerSchool.html|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=UC Santa Cruz|accessdate=10 Jan 2014}}</ref>
==== 2010 Summer School ====
The first UC-HiPACC summer school was held in July 2010 on the campus of UC Santa Cruz where students learned about the main software models currently used in high resolution simulations of galaxy formation and evolution. In labs, students worked on projects using these codes, supervised by the lecturers. The summer school was directed by [http://astronomy.nmsu.edu/dept/html/directory.faculty.aklypin.shtml Anatoly Klypin], [[New Mexico State University]].<ref>{{cite web|title=2010 International Summer School on Astro-Computing|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/html/2010SummerSchool_archive.html|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=UC Santa Cruz|accessdate=10 Jan 2014}}</ref>
==== 2011 Summer School ====
In 2011, 28 grad students — 17 from outside California — gathered at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory to learn about Explosive Astrophysics. The focus was on computational explosive astrophysics, including the modeling of core collapse and thermonuclear supernovae, gamma-ray bursts, neutron star mergers, and other energetic transients. Workshops guided students in running and visualizing simulations on supercomputers using codes such as FLASH, CASTRO, GR1D and modules for nuclear burning and radiation transport. The conference was organized by [http://astro.berkeley.edu/people/faculty/kasen.html Daniel Kasen] and [https://archive.is/20140113104528/http://astro.berkeley.edu/people/faculty/nugent.html Peter Nugent] of UC Berkeley and Lawrence Berkeley National Labs.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 International Summer School on Astro on AstroComputing|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/html/ISSAC_Home.php|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=UC Santa Cruz|accessdate=10 Jan 2014}}</ref>
==== 2012 Summer School ====
Taught from July 9 to 20, 2012, the summer school on the campus of [[UC San Diego]], under the direction of [http://www.sdss.jhu.edu/~szalay/ Alex Szaley], hosted by SDSC Director [https://web.archive.org/web/20070204003044/http://www.sdsc.edu/about/Director.html Michael Norman], taught the next generation of researchers how to deal effectively with the avalanche of data that comes from current astronomical observations. The field of study is called ''AstroInformatics.'' Students were afforded access to the San Diego Supercomputer Center for computational and infrastructure support. Conducted over 10 days, 30 hours of lectures, combined with five hours of post-lecture discussions, and 20 hours of hands-on computation labs.<ref>{{cite web|title=The 2012 International Summer School on AstroInformatics|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/ISSAC2012.html|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=UC Santa Cruz|accessdate=10 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Astroinformatics: 2012 Int'l Summer School on Astrocomputing|url=https://asaip.psu.edu/meetings/all-meetings/astroinformatics-2012-intl-summer|work=Astrostatistics and Astroinformatics Portal|publisher=Penn State|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref>
==== 2013 Summer School ====
The 2013 AstroComputing Summer School trained future researchers in the use of large-scale simulations in star and planet formation problems. The school covered many of the major public codes in use today, including tutorials and hands-on experience running and analyzing simulations. Student were led by instructors in labs on the new 3,000-core Hyades supercomputer<ref>{{cite web|last=Stephens|first=Tim|title=UCSC acquires powerful new astrophysics supercomputer system|url=http://phys.org/news/2013-07-ucsc-powerful-astrophysics-supercomputer.html|work=Phys.org|publisher=Science X network|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref> on the UCSC campus.<ref>{{cite web|title=International Summer School on AstroComputing 2013|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/ISSAC2013.html|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=UC Santa Cruz}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2013 UC-HIPACC International Advanced Summer School on Computational Astrophysics|url=http://aas.org/events/2013-03/%E2%80%9Cstar-and-planet-formation%E2%80%9D-theme-2013-uc-hipacc-international-advanced-summer-school|work=AAS Calendar|publisher=American Astronomical Society|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref>
=== Cosmological Simulations ===
Large cosmological simulations are now the basis for much current research on the structure of the universe and the evolution of galaxies and clusters of galaxies. “Numerical simulations have become ... one of the most effective tools to study and to solve astrophysical problems.”<ref>{{cite web|first1=Lauro |last1=Moscardini |first2=Klaus |last2=Dolag|title=Cosmology with numerical simulations|url=http://icc.ub.edu/~liciaverde/IC/como.pdf|work=Institute of Sciences of the Cosmos|publisher=Universitat de Barcelona|accessdate=9 Jan 2014}}</ref> Researchers associated with UC-HiPACC are deeply involved in the two projects described below, which are relevant to UC-HiPACC’s mission to promote UC computational astrophysics. The HiPACC website is hosting the Bolshoi website. The UCSC AstroComputing system Hyades, including the [[Huawei]] 1 [[Petabyte|PetaByte]] AstroData system, will be hosting many of Bolshoi simulation outputs.
==== Project AGORA ==== In 2012, the center launched a galaxy supercomputer simulation project called AGORA (Assembling Galaxies of Resolved Anatomy).<ref>{{cite web|title=Astrophysicists launch ambitious assessment of galaxy formation simulations|url=http://phys.org/news/2013-12-astrophysicists-ambitious-galaxy-formation-simulations.html|work=Phys.org|publisher=Science X network|accessdate=10 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ji-hoon|first=Kim|title=The AGORA High-resolution Galaxy Simulations Comparison|url=https://sites.google.com/site/santacruzcomparisonproject/home|publisher=Google Sites|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Project AGORA Home|url=http://www.agorasimulations.org/|work=Project AGORA: Assembling Galaxies Of Resolved Anatomy|publisher=UC Santa Cruz|accessdate=12 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Announcing project agora: Ambitious comparison of computer simulations of galaxy evolution|url=https://www.nsf.gov/news/news_summ.jsp?cntn_id=130020|work=National Science Foundation News|publisher=National Science Foundation|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Astrophysicists Launch Ambitious Assessment of Galaxy Formation Simulations|url=http://www.sciencenewsline.com/articles/2013121118410062.html|work=ScienceNewsline Sapce|publisher=ScienceNewsline|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bell|first=Trudy E.|title=AstroShort - December 2013. AGORA: Seeing the Invisible Elephant|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/AstroShorts/December2013.html|publisher=UC Santa Cruz|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|accessdate=10 Jan 2014}}</ref> <ref name=AGORA>{{cite web|last=Bell|first=Trudy E.|title=Worldwide Collaboration Announces Project Agora: Ambitious Comparison of High-Resolution Computer Simulations of Galaxy Formation and Evolution|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/PressRelease/AGORA.html|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=University of California|accessdate=10 Jan 2014}}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal|last=Ji-hoon|first=Kim|title=The AGORA High-Resolution Galaxy Simulations Comparison Project|publisher=Cornell University Library|date=1970|doi=10.1088/0067-0049/210/1/14|journal=The Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series|volume=210|pages=14|issue=14|arxiv=1308.2669|bibcode = 2014ApJS..210...14K }}</ref>
==== Bolshoi Simulation ====
The [[Bolshoi Cosmological Simulation]] (q.v.) is the most accurate cosmological simulation of the evolution of the large-scale structure of the universe made to date.<ref>{{cite web|last=Stephens|first=Tim|title=Scientists release most accurate simulation of the universe to date|url=http://phys.org/news/2011-09-scientists-accurate-simulation-universe-date.html|work=Phys.org|publisher=Science X network|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Primack|first1=Joel|first2=Trudy E.|last2=Bell|title=Universe on Fast Forward|journal=Sky & Telescope|date=July 2012|pages=28–35}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Jenvey|first=Karen|title=NASA Supercomputer Enables Largest Cosmological Simulations|url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/news/releases/2011/11-77AR.html|work=NASA Ames Research Center|publisher=NASA|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Stephens|first=Tim|title=Astrophysicists launch ambitious assessment of galaxy formation simulations|url=http://phys.org/news/2013-12-astrophysicists-ambitious-galaxy-formation-simulations.html|work=Phys.org|publisher=Science X network|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kanipe|first=Jeff|title=News: Cosmic simulation|url=http://delivery.acm.org/10.1145/2250000/2240241/p13-kanipe.html?ip=76.21.106.218&id=2240241&acc=OPEN&key=BF13D071DEA4D3F3B0AA4BA89B4BCA5B&CFID=281541822&CFTOKEN=58713661&__acm__=1389430999_7a0a9e26196e080d4ccdd9814b3382b2|work=Communications of the ACM|publisher=Association for Computing Machinery|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Tolentino|first=Mellisa|title=SiliconANGLE » The Origin Of The Galaxies: According To Pleiades The Supercomputer The Origin of the Galaxies: According to Pleiades the Supercomputer|url=http://siliconangle.com/blog/2011/10/04/the-origin-of-the-galaxies-according-to-pleiades-the-supercomputer/|work=SiliconANGLE|publisher=SiliconANGLE|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Boyle|first=Alan|title=How to build a virtual cosmos|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/science/how-build-virtual-cosmos-6C10402620|work=NBC News Science|publisher=NBC|accessdate=11 Jan 2014}}</ref>
=== Education of Public and Other Outreach ===
As UC-HiPACC states on its website, “A crucial goal of UC-HiPACC outreach is to give the fruits of UC computational astrophysics research back to the taxpaying public through formal (classroom) and informal (extracurricular) education.”<ref name=Outreach/>
Activities include the preparation by UC-HiPACC staff of articles to help astronomers reach classroom students and teachers and collaboration with planetaria, science museums, and other organizations that reach the astronomy-interested general public. Planetarium shows for which UC-HiPACC members have contributed astronomical computations and images include “Life: A Cosmic Story” in the 75-foot dome of the [[Morrison Planetarium]] in [[San Francisco]], and “Deep Space Adventure” in the 71-foot 8000 pixel-across dome of the [[Adler Planetarium]] in [[Chicago]].<ref name=Outreach/><ref>{{cite web|author=Morrison Planetarium|title=Life, A Cosmic Story, credits tab, Science Data and Simulations |url=http://www.calacademy.org/academy/exhibits/planetarium/life/|publisher=California Academy of Sciences|accessdate=13 Jan 2014}}</ref>
The UC-HiPACC staff creates and posts to its website approximately monthly “AstroShorts”—illustrated capsule stories about especially interesting work in computational astronomy around the UC-HiPACC consortium, designed for use in the newsletters of astronomical societies, science clubs, newspapers, or other outlets.<ref name=Outreach/> The website’s “Press Room” publishes press releases on computational astronomy from around the UC-HiPACC consortium.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/PressRoom.php|title=HiPACC Press Room |work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=UC Santa Cruz|accessdate=9 Jan 2014}}</ref> A visualization from the Bolshoi Cosmological Simulation, the most detailed cosmological simulation run to date, was narrated in the [[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]] TV special ''Inside the Milky Way''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Excerpts from "Inside the Milky Way", produced by National Geographic TV|url=http://hipacc.ucsc.edu/Bolshoi/Movies.html#insideMW|work=University of California High-Performance AstroComputing Center|publisher=UC Santa Cruz|accessdate=9 Jan 2014}}</ref> UC-HiPACC provided footage from the Bolshoi Simulation to the Icelandic performer [[Björk]] for her musical number “Dark Matter” for her [[Biophilia (album)|Biophilia]] concert.<ref name=Outreach/>
The organization conducts outreach to raise funds to support the activities described in this article.<ref name=Outreach/>

'''''Utopia for Realists: How We Can Build the Ideal World''''' is a book<ref>{{cite book|title=Utopia for Realists: How We Can Build the Ideal World|author=Rutger Bregman|isbn=978-0316471893| publisher=Little, Brown and Company/Hachette Book Group USA|date=2017-03-14}}</ref> by [[Rutger Bregman]] (born 1988). It was originally written as articles in Dutch for a virtual journal,<ref>[https://thecorrespondent.com/utopia-for-realists/ This book originated on The Correspondent]</ref> and since compiled and translated into several languages. It offers a [[Critical theory|critical]] proposal that it claims is a practical approach to [[Utopian socialism|reconstructing modern society]] to promote a more productive and equitable life based an three core ideas: * a universal and unconditional [[basic income]] paid to [[World population|everybody]] * a short [[Work week|working week]] of [[Working time|fifteen-hours]] * [[open border]]s worldwide with the free exchange of citizens between all nations
==Rationale== As a result of the advance of [[international trade]] and [[economic science]] in recent decades, globalization has radically transformed the traditional social and economic order from smaller, connected nations to a new [[world economy]] which, while already demonstrably capable of rescuing millions of people from poverty, could be extended to the entire human race.<ref>[http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_Forum_IncGrwth_2017.pdf World Economic Forum Growth Development Index 2017]</ref>
However, the new global system unfairly compensates a [[G20|few rich countries]],<ref>[http://www.oecd.org/eco/growth/2501905.pdf OECD:Trade Between Developed And Developing Countries': The Decade Ahead]</ref> and, with the progressive substitution of [[human capital]] with [[automation]] and [[robotics]],<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2014/01/23/robotics-and-automation-employment-and-aging-baby-boomers/ Robotics and automation, employment, and aging Baby Boomers]</ref> has also generated an increase in inequality, both between the [[capitalism|investment community]] and its [[workforce]]<ref>[http://www.epi.org/publication/the-decline-in-labors-share-of-corporate-income-since-2000-means-535-billion-less-for-workers/ EconomicPolicy Institute, 2015:The decline in labor’s share of corporate income]</ref> within the G20 nations as well as between [[developed country|developed countries]] and their [[Developing country|developing neighbours]].
==Justification== Each idea is [[critical theory|supported]] by multiple academic studies and anecdotal evidence including numerous success stories. For example, it quotes * Richard Nixon's 1968 plan for a basic income for Americans<ref>[https://www.jacobinmag.com/2016/05/richard-nixon-ubi-basic-income-welfare/ Jacobin:Nixon’s Basic Income Plan]</ref> * A [[Canada|Federal]] project in city of [[Dauphin, Manitoba]] once eradicated poverty<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/12/23/mincome-in-dauphin-manitoba_n_6335682.html Huffington Post;A Canadian City Once Eliminated Poverty And Nearly Everyone Forgot About It]</ref> * The perceived success of the [[Schengen Agreement]]<ref>[http://theconversation.com/business-will-suffer-if-border-crossings-between-european-neighbours-are-shut-47022 The Conversation (website): Business will suffer if border crossings between European neighbours are shut]</ref>
==Conclusion== {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2018}}
Bregman points out that many imperatives of modern law were once highly controversial proposals, perhaps even abhorrent innovations: * [[Abolition of slavery timeline|Abolition of slavery]] * [[Women's rights|Emancipation of women]] * [[LGBT rights by country or territory|Decriminalization of homosexuality]]
The author finally tries to provide a critical balance between [[Socialism|socialist]] ideals of caring and sharing, the [[Conservatism|conservative]] impetus of directive leadership, and [[Liberalism|liberal]] concepts of equality and freedom. He claims there are proven solutions waiting to be implemented, lacking only political courage and financial backing.
==See also== * [[Disclosing New Worlds]] * [[Social justice]] * [[Distribution of wealth]] * [[Income distribution]] * [[Protestant work ethic]] * [[Georgism]] * [[Critical theory]] * [[Critical thinking]] * [[Utopian socialism]] * [[Ethical socialism]]

[[File:Tellus - Ara Pacis.jpg|thumb|350px|A pair of ''velificantes'' on the [[Ara Pacis|Augustan Altar of Peace]] (late 1st century BC)]] '''''Velificatio''''' is a stylistic device used in [[Roman art|ancient Roman art]] to frame a [[List of Roman deities|deity]] by means of a billowing garment. It represents "vigorous movement," an [[theophany|epiphany]],Paul Rehak, ''Imperium and Cosmos: Augustus and the Northern Campus Martius'' (University of Wisconsin Press, 2006), p. 111. or "the vault of heaven," often appearing with celestial, weather, or sea deities.Robert Turcan, ''Les religions de l'Asie dans la vallée du Rhône'' (Brill, 1972), p. 21. It is characteristic of the [[iconography]] of the [[Aura (mythology)|Aurae]], the Breezes [[personification|personified]], and one of the elements which distinguish representations of Luna, the Roman [[Moon goddess|goddess of the Moon]], alluding to her astral course.Stefania Sorrenti, "Les représentations figurées de Jupiter Dolichénien à Rome," in ''La terra sigillata tardo-italica decorata del Museo nazionale romano'', «L'Erma» di Bretschneider, 1999), p. 370. A figure so framed is a '''''velificans''''' (plural '''''velificantes'''''). Not all deities are portrayed as ''velificantes'', but the device might be used to mark a member of the [[Roman Emperor|Imperial family]] who had been divinized (a [[Divus|''divus'' or ''diva'']]).Lise Vogel, ''The Column of Antoninus Pius'' (Harvard University Press, 1973), p. 45. ''Velificatio'' is a frequent device in Roman art,Hélène Walter, ''La Porte Noire de Besançon'' (Presses Univ. Franche-Comté, 1984), vol. 1, p. 332. including painting, [[mosaic]], [[relief]], and [[Roman sculpture|sculpture]], though it poses technical difficulties for freestanding sculpture. The Athenian sculptor [[Praxiteles]] was able to achieve it.Pliny, ''Natural History'' 36.29; Davide Stimilli, ''The Face of Immortality: Physiognomy and Criticism'' (State University of New York Press, 2005), p. 172. The term is also used to describe [[Hellenistic art]].Brunilde Sismondo Ridgway, ''Hellenistic Sculpture II: The Styles of ca. 200–100 B.C.'' (University of Wisconsin Press, 2000), ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=Y6Jj6rcIup4C&pg=PA124&dq=velificatio+OR+velificantes+OR+velificans&hl=en&ei=c5ZJTYfmBIKClAez4ZXYDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CEMQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=velificatio%20OR%20velificantes%20OR%20velificans&f=false passim.]'' The device continued to be used in later [[Western art history|Western art]], in which it is sometimes described as an ''aura'', "a breeze that blows from either without or from within that lifts the veil to reveal the face of an otherwise invisible being."The term is so used in the art criticism of [[Walter Benjamin]]; Aleida Assmann and Jan Assmann, "Air From Other Planets Blowing: The Logic of Authenticity and the Prophet of the Aura," in ''Mapping Benjamin: The Work of Art in the Digital Age'' (Stanford University Press, 2003), pp. 153–154. ==Usage and examples== In [[classical Latin]], the [[abstract noun]] ''velificatio'' is uncommon,It occurs in [[Cicero]], ''Ad familiares'' 1.9.21, and not again in Latin literature until Fronto, 267,4–5; Michel P.J. van den Hout, ''A Commentary on the Letters of M. Cornelius Fronto'' (Brill, 1999), p. 608. and refers to the act of setting sail, from ''velum'', "sail" (but also "cloth, garment, veil") and the ''-fic-'' combining element from ''-ficio, -ficere'' (= ''facio, facere'', "do, make"). The verbal form was the basis for modern scholarly usage. [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]] describes ''[[Aura (mythology)|Aurae]] velificantes sua veste'', the Breezes "making a sail with their own garment"[[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]], ''Natural History'' 36.29. at the [[Porticus Octaviae]] ("[[Portico]] of [[Octavia the Younger|Octavia]]").Thomas Köves-Zulauf, "Plinius d. Ä. und die römische Religion," ''Aufstieg und Niedergang der römischen Welt'' II.16.1 (1978), p. 277. Such depictions of the Aurae are known from extant Roman art, and have been used as comparative material to identify the pair of ''velificantes'' in a scene from the [[Ara Pacis|Augustan Altar of Peace]]. On the basis of a passage from the ''[[Carmen Saeculare]]'' of [[Horace]], composed and performed for [[Augustus]]'s staging of the [[Saecular Games]] in 17 BC, the central figure is often identified as Tellus (Earth):
Fertile in produce and cattle, let Tellus grant Ceres a crown of grain; let the healthful waters and breezes of Jove nourish offspring.''Fertilis frugum pecorisque Tellus / spicea donet Cererem corona; / nutriant fetus et aquae salubres / et Iovis aurae''.
Not all scholars agree on this analysis of the scene. The creatures on which the ''velificantes'' are seated also suggest [[Nereids]], and the reference may point to the [[Cult of the Nymphs]].Babette Stanley Spaeth, "The Goddess Ceres in the Ara Pacis Augustae and the Carthage Relief," ''American Journal of Archaeology'' 98 (1994), pp. 77–78. The significance of the veil is sometimes explained in terms of the [[initiation rite]]s of the [[mystery religions]]. Initiates wore drapery or a veil which was lifted by a priestess. The veil was a symbol of death, and its removal in the rite signified the initiate's rebirth. The ''velificatio'' thus appears in scenes on [[sarcophagi]] and in other [[funerary art]].Elisabeth Matelli, "Hieronymous in Athens and Rhodes", in ''Lyco of Troas and Hieronymous of Rhodes'' (Transaction Publishers, 2004), pp. 294–295. File:Villa dei Misteri V - 2.jpg|[[Villa of the Mysteries]] (1st century). File:The Kidnapping of Europa Mosaic.jpg|[[Europa (mythology)|Europa]] (mosaic, 1st-2nd century) File:Proserpina kidnapped Kircheriano Terme.jpg|[[Pluto (mythology)|Pluto]] (cinerary urn, 2nd century). File:Clipeus Selene Terme.jpg|[[Selene]] ([[clipeus]] from a [[sarcophagus]], early 3rd century). File:Sousse neptune.jpg|[[Neptune (mythology)|Neptune]] (mosaic, 3rd century). File:French Empire mantel clock.jpg|[[French Empire mantel clock]] (1822) depicting the nereid Galatea. ==List of ''velificantes''== The ''velificatio'' motif may be found with numerous deities, divine beings, and ''divi'', including:Unless otherwise noted, the following examples are given by Babette Stanley Spaeth, ''The Roman Goddess Ceres'' (University of Texas Press, 1996), p. 223. [[File:Enlèvement d'Europe by Nöel-Nicolas Coypel (detail).jpg|thumb|''Enlèvement d'Europe'' (1726–27) by [[Noël-Nicolas Coypel]]]] * [[Nyx]] * [[Aura (mythology)|Aura]] * [[Nereids]] * [[Horae]] (Seasons) * [[Maenad]]s *[[Niobids]] * [[Niobe]] *[[Selene]] or LunaParticularly on Roman-era sarcophagi that depict the myth of [[Endymion (mythology)|Endymion]]; Sorrenti, "Les représentations figurées," pp. 370, 376. * [[Helios]] * [[Caelus]]The figure at the top of the [[muscle cuirass|figured cuirass]] on the ''[[Augustus of Prima Porta]]'' is most often identified as Caelus; he is barechested with arms uplifted to support the ''velificatio''; Jane Clark Reeder, "The Statue of Augustus from Prima Porta, the Underground Complex, and the Omen of the Gallina Alba," ''American Journal of Philology'' 118 (1997), p. 109. The Caelus on the [[Belvedere altar]] is also a ''velificans''; Rehak, ''Imperium and Cosmos'', p. 111. * [[Europa (mythology)|Europa]] * [[Dionysus]] * [[Ariadne]] * [[Poseidon]] or [[Neptune (mythology)|Neptune]] * [[Amphitrite]] * [[Aphrodite]] or [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]] * [[Mars (mythology)|Mars]]On the [[muscle cuirass|cuirass]] of a statue in [[Cherchel]]; Rehak, ''Imperium and Cosmos'', p. 111. * [[Tarpeia]]On the [[Basilica Aemilia]] [[frieze]] in Rome; Rehak, ''Imperium and Cosmos'', p. 111. * [[Vibia Sabina]]Vogel, ''The Column of Antoninus Pius'', p. 45. ==See also== * [[Halo (religious iconography)]] * [[Aureola]] * [[Aura (paranormal)]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{italic title}} [[Category:Art criticism]] [[Category:Ancient Roman art]] [[Category:Roman Empire art]] [[Category:Ancient Roman religion]] [[Category:Religious symbols]] [[Category:Iconography]] [[Category:Visual motifs]]
